Germany is a leader in material science and mechanical engineering.Germany is sub-par in software engineering and in its physical communication infrastructure. This is in part due to persistent cultural wariness of surveillance technologies like social media. People aren’t keen to fund the infrastructure to make mass surveillance easier, and politicians don’t want to be seen as pushing for the capability.Germany also has the capability to advance nuclear technology, but doesn’t due to mass scientific illiteracy among the voting population that falselYou don’t advance technology as a monolith. Germany is a leader in material science and mechanical engineering.Germany is sub-par in software engineering and in its physical communication infrastructure. This is in part due to persistent cultural wariness of surveillance technologies like social media. People aren’t keen to fund the infrastructure to make mass surveillance easier, and politicians don’t want to be seen as pushing for the capability.Germany also has the capability to advance nuclear technology, but doesn’t due to mass scientific illiteracy among the voting population that falsely believes nuclear energy to be more dangerous than fossil fuels due to decades of propaganda by idiots.So no. Germany is not the most technologically advanced country. It could be pretty close, but there are major elements of society who dedicate themselves to making sure that Germany uses inferior technology that kills more people, damages the environment more, costs more money, and will cause the total collapse of Earth’s biosphere due to a runaway greenhouse effect. Mostly in the Green Party. Because radiation from nuclear accidents is apparently scarier than way more people dying of regular pollution constantly and the total annihilation of all life on Earth as the oceans boil away.

Answer: Psychologists are used to looking at people for indicators - it’s what many do for a living.We notice details, behavioral nuances, and listen carefully to what you say.…but saying that, we aren’t reading people, we’re usually just taking in what they put out there, and matching it to things we’re familiar with, and that’s just if they’re paying attention - everyone needs a break.The thing I always remember?Most people don’t show you who they are, they show you what they want you to see.Psychologists in a social setting aren’t trying to perpetually read others because they realize it’s not a trPsychologists are used to looking at people for indicators - it’s what many do for a living.We notice details, behavioral nuances, and listen carefully to what you say.…but saying that, we aren’t reading people, we’re usually just taking in what they put out there, and matching it to things we’re familiar with, and that’s just if they’re paying attention - everyone needs a break.The thing I always remember?Most people don’t show you who they are, they show you what they want you to see.Psychologists in a social setting aren’t trying to perpetually read others because they realize it’s not a true representation of most people.They aren’t asking questions to get to the core of who someone is, or having any real assessment - they’re just going with the flow, and taking in what you put out there.For most, they realize that what you put out there is not even close to a complete picture, and usually somewhat deceptive.Not that the people are always intentionally deceptive, it’s just that who we are in private, and deep in our person is often not the same….perhaps not as happy, kind, effusive, or a number of other traits you often see in public.Psychologists spend a lot of concentrated time with people one on one.I suspect that anyone who had that many conversations, and spent that kind of time would get pretty good at “reading people,” I’m just not sure that most people understand that there is so much more below the surface that simple interactions just don’t tell you.It’s why so many people make relationship mistakes every day.Just my opinion.

However, I am also a recently retired Silicon Valley engineer who worked most of his life developing that very technology that you think I am bad at. After working for Apple, Adobe, eBay, Microsoft, VMware, Cisco etc., I absolutely guarantee you that I know far more about any technology than anyone who is twenty years younger than me. I ought to, since I am one of the many hundreds of baby boomer engineers who actually invented the stuff. Who did you think invented it, young people? If they did they would havYou have made an assumption that is certainly not true in my case. I am 66 years old. However, I am also a recently retired Silicon Valley engineer who worked most of his life developing that very technology that you think I am bad at. After working for Apple, Adobe, eBay, Microsoft, VMware, Cisco etc., I absolutely guarantee you that I know far more about any technology than anyone who is twenty years younger than me. I ought to, since I am one of the many hundreds of baby boomer engineers who actually invented the stuff. Who did you think invented it, young people? If they did they would have needed a time machine.Please choose your misplaced stereotypes and “ageism”-influenced misconceptions more carefully in the future. If you try to paint a whole generation with one brush you are more often going to be wrong than you are right. People should be evaluated in-the-flesh as who they actually are, never by assumptions based on their age.
